content:
Hi, I’m new to Lean and I’m trying to clear up some confusion I have around which features are part of the kernel. I’ve played through the natural number game, I’ve read through a few blog posts and I’m partway through the Theorem Proving in Lean book.

My confusion is this: I have seen distinctions made between “term-style” and “tactic-style” proofs, and also between (paraphrasing) “proofs the kernel can check” and “tools that produce proofs the kernel can check”. 

Are these two distinctions equivalent; i.e. are “term-style” proofs exactly verifiable as-is by the Lean kernel? 

And does this mean that when I run #print theorem1 on a tactic-style proof, the output I get is a term-style proof that is directly verifiable by the kernel?
Term-style proofs aren't directly verifiable by the kernel — there are some features, like typeclass inference and implicit variable assignment that the kernel can't do
Thanks! So is running lean4export the only way to get a kernel-verifiable proof? Or is there a way to do this from within an interactive Lean session e.g. in VS Code?
You don't really want to see the gigantic term the kernel checks. set_option pp.all true gives you an idea (before a print)
Harald Carlens has marked this topic as resolved.
